pros:
No pros for a fresher except their mid-day free lunch. 

If you join as a fresher, assume your life is doomed ( They will take your confidence away. And make you feel like a slave in addition to the hostile environment they provide to you). If you want to join in this company, you better have an experience of 2-3 years and take their senior engineer role. Don't ever take their 'Engineer' or 'Assosciate Engineer' designation

Now, If you think I am writing this only because of my poor academic profile or having one bad experience in the company. Remove that from your mind. I cracked JEE with a rank below 500(gen. category), and I am one of the topper in my batch during my stay in IIT. And in Qualcomm, I worked in one of the best team (which is a emerging). I have been a crucial cog for some time as well.
cons:
Caution(freshers -don't join): Don't sway away by their no. 1 position in the processor market
"From 'making freshers feel hostile or not fit for the role given' to 'giving lots of work on a single day expecting to be like a senior'" - They do all these to a fresher.

Now, I am writing this only to caution freshers. They have zero tolerance to you, and once they feel you are lagging in some topic, they have this culture to not assign the work that you are lagging(they don't make you learn. Instead, they expect you to not lag every day, even if you are sick. And you need to fake if you want to be successful). Once they feel that you are bound to move out of the company, even-though it's after an year(u r thinking to move), they stop giving you work and make you feel stupid to be in the company. 

They will treat freshers with no respect. They will make freshers work like a slave (just like the ancient feudal system, here leads and managers are feudal lords and their juniors are their workers, who are bound to work for their lords). 

Freshers don't stay in this company for more than 2 years. They will get zero knowledge about the industry, if managers feel the fresher is bound to leave in such a manner(Managers will somehow make sure of this by not exposing you to the state-of-the-art). You need to be a fake of yourself to survive in this place (ironically, HRs want employees to be themselves and not a fake). You need to make your manager believe that you will stay in this company for your life-time(literally, lifetime). You need to fake in every meeting that you have understood the presenter's theory. If you question them, if he is your senior, then he will get angry and not give you work. Upper manager don't take you or your work or your ideas seriously. They make you feel you deserve a low-grade work and will take your confidence away.

I have experienced everything from being a worthless cog to becoming a crucial cog and again becoming a wortheless cog in the team after a while due to some personal reasons. But, one thing I can say is that I faked every minute, every day in this company, and faking in this company is taken as a success trait (for all the employees). As a fresher, my ideas were questioned in an illogical way by my seniors. Though after a while, they implemented the idea, my lead took the credit for implementing it (such an inhumane political act. The culture in this company itself is more political than hardwork. 

Company lives on hard-workjng people, but gives credit to political people ( from money to power). They will say they are crediting the management, because they are the one's who manages you. And you need to fake that you are in a complete agreement with this view.

I once again urge freshers(especially IITians) to not join this company. Along with your overall confidence and self-respect, you will also lose your health and will be prone to some life-style diseases (Such a hostile culture for an immature fresher).

review_title: Things have gone so wrong at Qualcommthat you have almost no chance to thrive through skills, hard work, and dedication.
job_title: Staff Systems Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
Still the wireless industry leader. 
Has enough cash to invest or waste.
Competitive total compensation in San Diego although benefits have been cut down significantly recently. (Compensation per unit hour is bad).
cons:
Favoritism has become the norm starting from hiring to assigning project tasks, and of course to promotions. 
Technical skills and knowledge has little value now. If you are technically sound and hard working/executing, but without the skills of buttering your bosses up, you won't reap any rewards these days. 
Introducing bugs and fixing them elevates visibility and is much more rewarding than doing quality work with no bugs at all. Complete U-turn from the original naming of "Qualcomm" as it derived from "Quality Communications".
Upper management is surrounded by cronies and they cronies sell mostly their own interests to them. They present others works as their own achievement. So, the engineers who are doing the actual job are rewarded very little or nothing compared to how much hard work and sacrifice they make. 
The upper management is out of touch from recent technologies and not motivated either. This is killing innovation and ingenuity here. Their and cronies narrow views have become the views of the company overlooking any other options/ides.
There are too many VPs and senior directors who do not contribute, but draws huge salary and benefits at the cost of salary/benefits to young and mid-level engineers. Career advancement is almost saturated.
Engineers are over worked days, nights, and weekends while the benefits go to others. Considering the long hours and weekend works, the compensation is not good at all.

review_title: A restful haven for the mediocre, inexperienced, lazy, and apathetic
pros: If you want to live in San Diego, this is more or less the biggest game in town if you're a software developer (or - better yet - a hardware engineer). The commute is moderately tolerable - even if it sometimes takes more than an hour to get to work from downtown San Diego - and the benefits are decent. It's kind of like working for a solid B-list company in Silicon Valley.
cons:
QUALCOMM seems to be infested with employees who essentially got lucky: they somehow stumbled into a position with QCOM back in the early 1990s and worked their way into a more prestigious position with big cash prizes, stock grants, and so on. Sadly, this means that as a new hire you'll be faced with an impenetrable old boys' (or girls') network: as an outsider, you will never, ever be promoted.

Many employees are minimally competent at best, and the company has embarked on aggressive cost cutting measures, so be prepared for a lot of offshoring hassles (think 6am meetings with India) as well as deep disconnects in terms of cross-cultural communication and technical competence.

review_title: Pleasant place to work if you are OK with just "going with the flow"
job_title: Product Marketing Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
Cash compensation is very good relative to other companies.
Business is growing rapidly since the company is in a relatively good market.
As of this writing, company was acquired by a much larger, very profitable company which would likely ensure job security.
Company really does an excellent job making it a very family-friendly place to work - the work life balance is second-to-none.
cons: Lots of middle management and politics - the company promotes a lot of its early employees, which in principle is a great idea.  There are often more directors and senior directors on a team than actually rank and file employees!  However, the rapid growth of the business shortcuts a lot of the professional development that these managers needed to successfully manage the products and growth to be scalable in years to come.  As such, a lot of projects are done without proper planning and a lot of inefficiencies are present.  New management teams have been brought in from the outside only to be rendered powerless by existing management.

review_title: Not too fast paced, but not much sense of accomplishment
job_title: Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
Note that these are team specific (Android), experience may vary across teams/depts
- very flexible hours
- relatively few meetings to waste development time
- you get to see commercial devices before they actually release
- great pay for the kind of work you do, its a bargain actually.
- awesome benefits, has a nurse-practitioner on site for any illnesses, injuries
cons:
- low sense of accomplishment
- software is mostly involved in testing/bug fixing, if lucky you may get to work on big projects but you have to chase down managers for more important work
- repetitive work, one chip after another is mostly the same stuff on different hardware
- poor coding practices in certain teams, bad function names and mispellings get propagated because nobody ever steps up to fix them.
- 3 years average promotion time for engineers, which seem to be longer than alot of other companies, this adds to the lack of accomplishment
- line management, your line manager has no clue what you did in the past quarter nor do they care.  They evaluate you based on an online form filled out by your colleagues and given the impersonal nature of the evaluation (no personal interaction), people get bored of bubbling things in and writing canned answers they just dont try to write anything amazing about you.
- they give you lots of bonuses and stock options to keep you here, but rarely actually bump your salary

review_title: Great place if you like change and great people.
job_title: Marketing Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: People.  (There are some not so great ones but won't take you long to figure out who they are).  Lots of support, IT, Health Center, Learning Opportunities, New Facilities, Offices for almost everyone, farmers markets in the summer, movie screenings in their lecture hall where you can bring your family, etc. they definately take care of their employees for the most part.  They try to make the workplace fun.  Always changing. Sr. Executives are very approachable. (SVP and up)
cons: always on.  The expectation is that if they are paying your cell bill, you should answer after hours. I can appreciate that and don't mind but some people might.  It really depends on the supervisor you have. decision by consensus becomes exhausting. New ideas take a while for people to warm up to, if you're persistant then you should be just fine. like I said above, change. Personally I like but if you like the same structure year after year, this place isn't for you.  Agility is key to being happy here. Middle managment (Sr. Dir/ Dir. are usually at the stage in their career where they are in it for themselves and don't look after their employees unless you luck out.)  I work in marketing and with it beng a engineering centric company (as it should be) Marketing gets little money and support in general. Sometimes you luck out and get an executive who really believes in the power of it and magically things happen for that marketing group. (more money, higher exposure etc).

review_title: Company has interesting technology and variety or work, need help in managment
pros: Qualcomm is a hotbed for learning about wireless technology being the 900lb Gorilla of CDMA/WCDMA technology.  There is a diverse variety of work within Qualcomm that has the potential to allow you to move between department and get a variety of experience.  Work/life balance is respected and employees are taken care of from this perspective.  Pay and benefits are above the average.
cons: Your career depends on your management and your site.  Senior management appears to have good direction and run the company quite well.  Based on my experience, middle management appears to be the problem.  Quality work goes unnoticed, unless your project has high visibility.  Many groups are quite disorganized and have little to know understanding of a proper software development lifecycle processes.  There are some exceptions within the organization, but they are the exceptions, not the norm.  Feedback is generally ignored at best.  Promotion is based far more on longevity than on ability.  This leads to a middle management that may or may not have any ability to deliver product.  The company attempts to run as a large collection of independent startups with little to know oversite by the corproation.  This leads to a wide variety of quality standards and no accountability for project failure.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Very smart high-quality people with solid technical skills. A "democratic" environment where you can organically grow and nurture original ideas by identifying and working with a network of advocates. Good work life balance. Good benefits.
cons: Perhaps due to transitioning from a small to a large firm in a short-span of time, there is intense inter-office politics. Too many people in mid/upper management holding those positions solely due to longevity and not due to competence. One can easily see that the smarter younger talent is stifled by incompetent older people who just "hang around" year after year. Now with the cuts and layoffs, it is as if the merry-go-round has "frozen" and everyone is hanging tight to their seats. Even if one isn't being laid off, it isn't hard to feel that one's career is going nowhere here. There is no opportunity for growth and therefore no excitement to work here anymore.

pros: There are very few pros....after over a year I had to get out of this nut house.  Firethorn is a wholly owned subsidiary of Qualcomm in Atlanta. The employees enjoy all of the standard benefits Qualcomm is so well known for (great health plan, dental, stock options etc.).  They do NOT enjoy any of the on site benefits other Qualcomm, San Diego employees have (a clinic, a dentist, childcare etc.).  Buckhead is a great location to work.
cons:
If you want to work at Qualcomm, move to San Diego.
Firethorn, may be owned by Qualcomm but it is not Qualcomm in its environment. To make matters worse, Qualcomm seems to care little about this business unit or the people there.  It is truly a terrible place to work.  The Firethorn Management team (aka the Inner Circle) is inept to a degree I have never experienced before. They are blind to the problems within the business unit and are driving the business into the ground, abandoning the core business line. Essentially they are treading water until they themselves can all leave with their stock options and new lives. 
If you are looking for a career path with Qualcomm, you will NOT find it here. No one outside of the Inner Circle (they sometimes refer to themselves as this) ever really moves up.  There is no HR presence at Firethorn, only policies to snuggle up to.  Lastly, there is no accountability or guidance. Firethorn is appropriate named.  You will feel the sting from day one.

job_title: Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
Great benefits package, including awesome health insurance packages. I don't think health insurance can be better anywhere else. ESPP is great, but not as good as before. Raises are given twice a year, so it's somewhat better than other companies, but base salary is not that great.

Also Qualcomm is one of Fortune's best companies to work for, so people respect it a lot.
cons:
CDMA technologies can only go so far. Qualcomm used to be a great place many years ago, with CEO Irwin Jacobs. I don't believe that Paul Jacobs and the rest of senior management know how to innovate anymore. 

Also some managers do not appreciate their workers as much as others. Work can get pretty intensive and competition can be fierce even among fellow employees. People are expected to work overtime all the time, without a significant increase in pay or bonus. Also convoluted politics, especially  those among managers who favor some folks over others, not because of their performance but because of personal favoritism, don't help. Many managers & HR folks are dishonest when disclosing information to workers. Because of this, it can be a hostile environment sometimes.

job_title: Staff Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
Market leader
Management has repeatedly shown knack of being at right place (technology/product wise) at the right time
Excellent benefits - especially gold plated health plan
Very bright people
Qualcomm is an excellent company which has execution at all costs as its DNA.  This has served the organization well as they have been able to capture the cellular market with being able to deliver extremely quickly while others have struggled.
cons:
The dark side is the human cost of the execution driven culture.  There is absolutely no respect for the personal life of the engineers.  People are supposed to be able to drop everything at a moment's notice to work round the clock for months including days, nights, weekends etc.  

Mid-level managers threaten (by extensive name dropping), cajole and browbeat people into making them work crazy hours.

The reason for all this is the explosion of products in the last few years.  There is surprisingly little commonality and leverage between products and the feature combinations are so numerous that a lot of engineering time is spent repeatedly integrating and verifying legacy features.  In addition the development environment and tools are abysmal.  Given the stressful environment and lots of grunt work there is very little professional growth.

job_title: Business Development in San Diego, CA
pros: In past years, I would have given this company 5 stars in every category.  The past 2 years has been extremely difficult with many employees being laid off, most of them quietly without much fanfare.  Of course, there's the huge layoff that occurred in September where over 4000 will lose their jobs on November 20.  Overall, the company has been a wonderful place to work -- great benefits, smart people, unique culture, and a passion for innovation.  In recent years, because of change in executive management ranks, the company is losing its unique culture.  Due to the focus on cutting costs, the benefits have been scaled back significantly, the passion for innovation is not as infectious as it used to be, and it is clear the culture at the company is in transition.
cons: People are afraid to lose their jobs.  People are grateful for surviving the latest reduction in force only to worry about whether or not they'll make the next cut.  After cutting its workforce by 15% in September-November time period, the remaining 85% of the employees at QCOM are asked to continue doing their jobs with fewer resources.  The competitive environment is tougher now, and it will be interesting to see whether or not this company will survive the long term.

pros:

cons:
- Don't come here if you're a software engineer.  You will be treated as a cog in a machine.
- Disturbing lip service to a certain set of fashionable corporate values.
- Very corrupt behavior in the markets it enters.
- Management is unstable and tends to pursue goals half-heartedly, then cheap-out, I've seen it happen a dozen times.  The 810 chipset fiasco is the latest in a long series of examples.
- Annoying history of advising management to go in a certain direction, almost getting fired for "saying something crazy", then whole company was forced in that strategic direction 3 months later by the good sense of outside competitors, it happened many times, my career was almost destroyed each time, especially after I was proven right.

I worked there for a total of 12 years, and the only way for an american to get promoted is to leave the company and then return in a different department.  It's astonishing that they can pay a senior engineer $130k but managers start at $180k, the company is top-heavy with slick, overpaid managers who contribute very little to the bottom line.  In my experience, you can get a great review when there is no money for bonuses and no stock available, but when there is something valuable on the table, it always seems to go to "friends" of management, and I mean that not in a good way ...

review_title: Qualcomm has become a factory, there is no work life balance
pros:
You are working with the undisputed leader in the wireless and mobile market.
Great name to have on the resume.
Free breakfast , lunch , snacks, soft drinks, cab facilities and on site gym. 
Working on cutting edge technologies.
Very good base compensation. RSU's are absolutely amazing , they simply cannot be matched by any VLSI company.
cons:
Extremely long working hours especially in the Physical Design group. You can end up working 100 hours  week along with full night outs. Even after doing a night out , you might still be bashed by your manager for not doing this and that.

Because of the aggressive work schedules , people are expected to be available almost every time, whether its late night or weekend or holidays. Management is treating engineers like slaves. Forget work life balance, this is not the place to be in when you have a family. 

They do not care whether you are sick , or dying due to a heart attack, they will still call you to check the ETA of your deliverable!

Due to big volume of work, quality takes a beating, the emphasis is on 'somehow' completing your work, and the only thing discussed in the meetings is ETA. Everybody is working in a factory mode, slogging round the clock , without any innovative thinking. This place works likes a factory!!

Generous RSU's and their vesting period are one big reason why people wont leave Qualcomm even with this bad culture.

review_title: Overall good company going through some rough times
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Overall treats employees well, but this is at a corporate level.
cons:
Some departments are run very poorly, and executive management either doesn't notice or doesn't care.  How much you enjoy working at Qualcomm will depend on your chain of management, some people have good managers, some have very poor managers.  Unfortunately, there are a quite a number of poor managers who tend to promote people like them, resulting in more poor managers, but this is a common corporate problem that is not unique to Qualcomm.

The company is going through some rough times at the moment and is trying to modify their business as the mobile phone market matures.  This has resulted in reduced profits, which in turn has resulted in decreased bonuses and stock awards.  This action is completely understandable, and I do not fault them for having to do this.  Unfortunately, for certain employees whose overall compensation is heavily based on receiving stock, this has resulted in a compensation level that is no longer competitive with the market.  Hopefully the company will get back on track and have an improved financial outlook sooner rather than later.

review_title: Stimulating work environment, smart colleagues, great benefits and work/life balance - but big company growth blues
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Working at Qualcomm (in particular in the San Diego headquarters) offers great learning from all sources everyday - colleagues, countless seminars, technology fairs, etc. Excellent work culture for the most part, good employees are respected and rewarded.
cons:
Qualcomm has grown to be a large company, in particular in the last 10 years. The work culture and growth potential have, naturally, evolved accordingly. This means:

(1) Although the company is innovating in multiple new technology areas, in most parts of the company, innovation is recognized and rewarded only in the more traditional (3G, 4G) technologies.

(2) Qualcomm has become a very top heavy company. Due to the incumbents who started in the company early, and never left, low outside opportunities in the San Diego area, and simply the company being a great place to work, the layer of SVPs and VPs is huge.

(3) There is a good chance that younger and very talented engineers will be (are) frustrated, as promotions are, to a great extent, a slave of "protocol", which is applied in equal measure to everyone - regardless of talent. ("Although you're outstanding, we cannot promote you in two years because on average it takes four, etc.").

review_title: A great place to start your career, but keep your eyes open for other opportunities
pros:
- Casual culture and flexible working hours.
- Some very smart colleagues.
- Leader in wireless chipset business.
- You will learn a lot about the product and how to tackle some complex challenges.
cons:
- Experience depends A LOT on what group you are in and how well the work is aligned with your interests.  It is very easy to become pigeonholed into working solely on an obscure feature (such as some module of a particular chipset that does X).  
- Effort over results: promotion is largely based on how long you have been at Qualcomm, not necessarily your effectiveness as an engineer.  There is also the pressure to show that you have been working hard by sending useless e-mail updates at late hours.
- Very process-oriented: on an e-mail thread with a technical issue, a common tactic is to incrementally CC higher-ranked engineers/managers to passive-aggressively attempt to expedite progress.  What starts as an e-mail exchange about an issue reported by a customer rapidly turns into a 50 e-mail long thread with at least 2 VP-level engineers, 5 senior staff, 10 senior engineers, etc.  Too many meetings.
- Large duplication of effort;  there are a lot of similar projects between different divisions, such as QCT and Corporate R&D.  
- Relatively low salary;  HR needs offer more compelling reasons to stay at Qualcomm other than the San Diego beach lifestyle.

cons:
Benefits shrinking rapidly — no more accrued vacation time. Also, with repeated layoffs and understaffed departments, it’s near Impossible to find a time “convenient to the business” to take any time off.   Headcount is cut in half in some areas while workload only grows, and there is no concern for employee welfare and how to resolve tired over-worked  employees having unrealistic workload to manage. New merit review system removes manager ability to individually reward high performers (it is all decided by compensation team).  High performers are given minuscule salary increases below cost of living increase; how does this
motivate anyone? No end in sight to mountains of work growing with no plans to add resources, only more reductions.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: 1.  Pay is above average for the area & benefits are comprehensive.
cons:
1.  Incredibly political atmosphere fosters hostility and resentment among employees.  Many of the "Qualcomm lifers" are there to "rest and vest" and are incredibly resentful of newcomers.
2.  Extremely top heavy company with excessive amounts of upper management who expect the few non-management employees to do all of their work for them with no assistance, or guidance.  Many Managers, Directors and VPs have no direct reports, and many departments have more management-level employees than not.
3.  The company panders to the short-term whims of their investors, at the long-term cost of the company.  One only needs to look at the on-going "cost reduction initiative" to save $1 billion to realize this.  The company announced the initiative a few days before being slapped with around $1 billion in regulatory fines.  Instead of adjusting their business model to prevent even further regulatory damages (QC has been slapped with major fines by Korea, China, and the EU to name a few), they insist on continuing with their controversial business model and instead choose layoff thousands of employees once more.  Additionally, as part of the initiative there are no opportunities for internal transfers resulting in a mass exodus of much of the company's young, top talent.

The bottom line:  I had high hopes for this company when I first started.  Unfortunately, Qualcomm is a sinking ship.  It's only a matter of time before all of their top young talent leave for another company that will do right by it's employees and investors, a company with a sustainable vision for the future, in addition to equitable pay.

CONSTANT downgrades in everything compared to what it was in the last 10 years... from the quality of toilet paper, removal of reverse osmosis water filters, health plan, Qualstar ($100 peer rewards down to $50), removing access to JCC gyms, charging $4 monthly for 401K, canceling end-of-the-year parties, etc.
The IT department at Qualcomm used to be world-class. They've outsourced it and nowadays it's a total waste of time; "let me research that" is a typical answer when you ask IT a question - total waste of resources. Laptop refreshers take 5+ years and engineers get stuck with old, outdated equipment. CEO & Jacobs each took $59 million in bonus a few years ago when employees were getting laid off. HR typically shows you their middle finger if you ask for a market adjustment (I'm at 92% according to them, and I asked for one - they gave me %0.1 raise ... yes, that's tenth of 1 percent). Initially when they downgraded the health plan a few years ago, the physical flyers that were mailed to us read something along the lines of "the details of your health plan UPGRADE"... downright twisted. All that said, HR is making promotions beyond Staff level very difficult to impossible - good luck with that career growth if you join

job_title: Senior Programmer/Analyst in San Diego, CA
pros: Pretty good company if you want to work at a Fortune 100 company. They love to tout that as a reason to sign on with them. The benefits package is very good as far as healthcare goes. But the stock options are also usually given to new employees. Check the market to see what those are worth.
cons:
Salaries are lower than the rest of the industry. The "you should be glad you work here we're a Fortune 100 company" predominates. Management is completely clueless. They build products and have no idea how to bill for them or if there is even a market for them. Lot's of poor planning resulting in ill defined last minute projects. Your expected to work at least 60 hours a week for weeks on end. As an exempt employee you end up working for near half salary.   

Look elsewhere unless you like 60+ hour weeks and not seeing your family. The stock options are worthless and the stock hasn't risen in years. Stay out of QUALCOMM Enterprise Services, that business unit is dying on the vine it is just a shrt matter of time before they cut that unit loose to flounder on it's own.

review_title: Used to be great, going downhill at alarming rate
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer/Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Had a scrappy, start up feel to it until a few years ago to the point that it was famous as one of the most nimble big companies around. Personally I had a great career at Qualcomm, starting as contractor and ending as Sr Staff/Mgr in 8 years. I consider myself fortunate to have joined while the start up vibe was still around.
cons: Sadly, in the past 2-3 years, the company began to rest on its laurels and shun all risks. It was as though the entire senior management collectively  went into "rest and vest" mode. Management kept talking about "Adjacent markets" to phone/tablet business without ever tracking it seriously. This despite the well known risks of depending on just two major customers for the bulk of its phone business. The results are now painfully obvious to see. Sadly, it is the rank and file engineers that are getting laid off and not the execs that blundered in the first place. The topping on the cake was labelling this the "Qualcomm way".

job_title: Senior Director in San Diego, CA
pros: Brilliant people drive themselves to win, and the company won big over decades.  Priceless experience you can't get elsewhere.  Launching technology around the world, and changing the world in a big way.
cons: Unfortunately morale has gone down over the past couple years.  Quite a bit in 2018, after some significant layoffs.  You will work long hours, but it's been that way for decades.  Expect that in any tech company these days.  All this "work life balance" stuff you see is not true - anywhere.   Tech advances more rapidly year over year.  If you are excited about the work and fruits of the company's labor, you don't think so much about the balance.  That's the way it was until a couple years ago.   Now it's more thinking about the balance and if you really want to continue working there.   Ratings in all categories below would be higher if rated 2+ years ago.

job_title: Staff Staffing Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros: The people.  The technology.  The excitement.   Always so much to learn here and each day is different.  There are many support structures here (tools/team/mgmt) and communication flows very well.  Qualcomm is a big company, yet moves very quickly in an ever changing/evolving market place.  We are very well positioned in multiple areas these days.  QCT Chips are selling more than ever and CDMA continues to expand (WCDMA/CDMA2000), MediaFLO (broadcast mobile TV), Firethorn (mobile commerce), QIS (Brew apps, Qchat).  QC continues to spend over $1B a year in R&D and we are coming out with many compelling products.  From multiple personal devices, to medical, to logistics, etc.
cons: None that I have come accross in my two years.  I have worked for about 10 other companies over the last 10 years (most have been contracts) and I am more impressed with what I see here at QC than at any other place I have worked at.  They really take care of their people here and our attrition rate is incredibly low - MUCH lower than industry standard - which says a lot.  I am, for the first time in nearly a decade, still excited about my career and QC.  I finally found a place in which I want to work for long term and build my career.

pros: Opportunity to travel around the world. Used to be able to fly business class. Working with smart and driven people
cons: The culture is absolutely terrible. Within my team, turnover was more than 50% last year. People dropped like flies. Why? Because management only cares about meeting its numbers. They do not care if they kill their staff in the process of doing so, by making them work insane hours and jump through hoops just to meet expectations. As long as they hit their goals and look good in front of their managers, they're happy. Management will lie to you about promotion potential from day 1 (interviews). They will keep dangling the potential to be promoted in front of you, just to get you to work harder for them. In the end, you (along with many others who were promised the same thing) will be sorely disappointed. I joined the company thinking it would be great, that it was the best place to work in San Diego, but trust me, it's not worth the pain, sweat, and tears to have the "Qualcomm" name on your resume.

job_title: Senior Staff Engineer/Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: In terms of benefits Qualcomm is excellent. Free gym, good 401k match, good pay, decent bonuses and stock options, excellent health care (free), many employee programs, lots of tech training, nice campus, onsite cafeterias - you name it.
cons: The company is a dinosaur. The management structure is deep with many redundant levels and political power structures. Decisions are not made for technical reasons but rather to benefit your Director or VP. There are periodic layoffs that tend to hit the lowest performers first, but they also lay off those who do not "fit in" (ie. anyone who actually has good ideas and is somewhat vocal.) Job performance is increasingly about perception rather than results. Career advancement varies great between departments. If you are lucky enough to have a benevolent manager you'll get promoted every few years, if you have a bully you'll be forever stuck in the same role (ie. 10 years or more) since you're not deemed worthy despite all your excellent reviews. Qualcomm could easily reduce headcount by 75% and still keep their core businesses: Modem and MSM. They are and old, slow, flabby company that is only focused on cost reduction rather than innovation.

review_title: Exccelllent organization, challenging work, great co-workers and a good market position.
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer/Manager in San Diego, CA
pros:
You will be working with some of the best people in the trade. Qualcomm has been carving a stronger and stronger market position for itself.  This makes the company comfortable in taking risks (nor all of which pay off) - hence innovations is highly prized (second only to execution) 

Compensation is good. The company adjusts to any changes in the external marketplace readily and quickly. This means that it shall not be the "most' you can get - but you will be very close - and hopefully the other intangibles will more than make up for any difference. 

People at Qualcomm are very helpful and collaborative. Team spirit is present everywhere. Generally speaking everyone is competent and many are arguably the best in the business.
cons:
With a few exceptions, Qualcomm does not make end products directly. It must read the minds of large cell phone makers, network providers etc.  There is always a difference that must be compensated when shipping the product. 

So, in several teams - especially which work on customer facing roles,  life shall be very busy - and even chaotic - with a lot of pressure. If there is factory that has stopped making phones - or a phone's launch is at stake - all because of a bug you are working on, the pressure (and visibility) can be intense.

review_title: Not the worst place to work at
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
Stuff you work on will generally be interesting 
Coworkers are  pretty good
Solid process for programmers (versioning systems, code review etc) 
Large enough teams so work is evenly distributed 
Good opportunity to be exposed to new things 

Best pro is that I'm usually into my work enough that time passes by quickly and I'm generally excited for Mondays.
cons:
No commitment to flow of knowledge. You can often be assigned to a unfamiliar project with very little idea of what you're supposed to do. (the project lead will have the high level overview but good luck getting him to explain it to you). More often than not it's baptism by fire. To be fair they're getting better about documentation now
Code quality varies across teams, drastically. A lot of legacy code needs be maintained. 
Work load very unpredictable. There are weeks when you have nothing to do, and weeks where 24 hours isn't enough in a day. 
Some of the higher level managers have overly aggressive in deadlines and no one bothers reigning them in
Too much administrative crud (I assume it's everywhere). 
Pay comparatively sucks.

review_title: Your mileage may vary depending on the management chain above you
job_title: Staff Product Manager in San Diego, CA
pros:
At the working cross - functional level, the teamwork is phenomenal.  In fact, I would say that is the key to Qualcomm's success has been the quality of the teams executing.  There is a lot of mutual respect and get the job done can do attitude.   A lot of smart people that work incredible hours to achieve success.  I have nothing but good things to say about the people i worked with on a day-by-day basis. 

Good compensation and benefits.
cons: In some departments, the management chain is dysfunctional.  In my particular experience, some of us at the working level were excluded and isolated from information from above but at the same time, being held accountable to act with that information.  VP and SVP levels clearly lack leadership skills or the ability to leverage the people under them in an effective, unified team.   Again, this is not universal across Qualcomm.  It all depends on which department you end up.

cons: A comfortable market positioning may and does go to the head.  In this case, the products are hashed as fast as possible and quality suffers.  Projects are typically run with impossible schedules and thus heroism is rewarded, no matter what kind of problems a rushed project may have.  Consequently, what is considered going the extra mile in other companies, even in the industry, comes to be expected, to the detriment of life outside the workplace.  Moreover, since pulling out the improbable is rewarded, team-work suffers, not only among team members, but especially across teams.  There's not a clear technical career path, resulting in many engineers finding themselves without an alternative but to become managers to advance their careers, often with poor managerial skills or training.

In the 3 years I have been here, my team has only had 1 team building event and there have only been 2 company events, 1 for a 25 year anniversary

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: One of my favorite things about working at Qualcomm is that employees at any level can perform meaningful work and turn great ideas into incredible success stories.  There are a lot of smart, talented, and energetic employees here who care a lot about the work they do.
cons: While employees have shown their passion for the work they do and their commitment to Qualcomm, it has really started to feel like unreciprocated love.  Management has become very bottom-line driven, in many instances penny-smart, pound foolish, and it has sent a terrible message to employees that they are not valued.  When I moved across the company to join Qualcomm, it was a company advertised as one of Fortune's top 100 companies, and I was awe stricken by the fact they paid 100% of healthcare costs for employees and their families.  Neither of those things are true anymore, and the negative changes have piled up in the last 12-18 months (cuts to benefits, bonuses, stock, headcount reductions, reputation).

review_title: It is a shame that Irwin Jacobs has to watch idiots wreck what he built
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA

pros: They pay you a salary
cons:
Support services are in chaos, IS have had experienced staff and managers fired, you deal with someone with a script in a call centre somewhere on the other side of the world who is polite but clueless. Calls are then lost and must be chased daily for weeks before anything happens.
Director to President level managers all act like they are petrified of being fired and are much more worried about covering their rears and looking good than about actually solving any problems. Bucks get passed instead of issues being worked on, it's like being in a giant game of pass the parcel with the prize inside being a ticking bomb.
Promotions are rationed and handed out to favourites rather than on the basis of ability.
Everybody is terrified of making commitments in case they can't meet them, so rather than make a decision people call a meeting and try to delegate or escalate until they are off the hook.
San Diego is the centre of the universe, but don't have a clue about time zones and expect UK to work on their schedule then act all hurt if we don't want to routinely turn up to meetings scheduled at midnight.
Management keep saying "no more headcount reductions" rapidly followed by another round of sackings. Do they think we are too stupid to notice?
I worked at CSR for over a decade before it was taken over by Qualcomm, it's impressive how fast they have turned around the company and made it into a disfunctional nightmare.

job_title: Senior Staff Hardware Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Smart co-workers; Good work environment; Great learning opportunities.  CEO seems to have a clearer path forward.  Solid world class IP.  Great roadmap.  Good C-suite team.
cons:
Promotions are given for time in the seat.  When you are up for promotion, the first thing they want to know is "how long have they been in the position?".  So much for merit.  This kills motivation and promotes cruising for a few years.

Women seem to get stuck in middle management.  I think the old sayig that "people hire those that are like themselves" is in play for the executives.  This is also true of the various cultures hired.  Each group seems to hire their own culture and even speak in their native language in San Diego.  If you go to the cafeteria, it is like the Wild Animal Park where the same "types" of people congregate together, just like at the park where similar type animals congregate together.  Nothing wrong with that except that mentality seems to translate to hiring.  

If you are from Southern California, you will feel you are in Asia at this company, except for the old timers.  

I have no clue what my management's goals are all the way up the chain, CEO excluded.  This seriously limits my ability to help them achieve their goals.

review_title: A political quagmire orchestrated by managers too busy proving how smart they are
job_title: Business Development in San Diego, CA
pros: Good benefits, very talented engineers, not too bureaucratic for a company of its size
cons:
At least 50% of the managers are totally incompetent as managers. They are busy playing politics all day long and trying to force their agenda on others. Most managers act like individual contributors whose directs exist for the sole purpose of cleaning their leftovers. 
Agreeing on expectations, providing feedback, asking instead of commanding and coaching is something I haven't seen from any manager in this company. This is all a result of a poor management culture and promotion for the wrong reasons. The organizational hierarchy is so vertical that most managers have fewer than 4 directs. This means you need to to fill an awful lot of management positions from a pool for technocrats, how well can this turn out to be? Senior management is completely detached. To illustrate it, 16,000 company employees (60%) report to a single manager who sits 3 levels below the CEO.

pros: Great benefits. Lots of opportunities for training on site. Keeps up with technology trends. I like the culture's values and events the company tries to push but not every group behaves like that.
cons:
Management requirements vary widely among managers. Some will allow working from home and will provide work loads that result in normal working hours. Others will push for a lot of on-site overtime. Qualcomm seems to have a lot of head count one year and little in another year which can make it difficult to transfer if you dislike your situation during a lean year.

Felt like there were too many people on projects for the scope of work. Made it difficult to own things and provide a meaningful contribution. The projects I was on seemed to move really slowly and my management often blamed the PM for this. We had PMs rotate on and off a lot and quit in this environment. Only one of them stayed with the company for more than a yea but this person found a way to transfer.

For some reason, rarely saw people promoted past staff level if they came in at a lower level such as senior. This was even among people there for more than 5-10 years. Many other companies you can work your way up higher in that timeframe.

review_title: Once a superb technology oriented company now losing direction
pros: Latest wireless silicon, powerful apps processors, bright coworkers and fast paced environment. Very good  infrastructure and facilities such as library, gyms, cafeteria etc.
cons:
Too much politics. Too many high titled folks earn their pay by sending emails day in day out. Don't know what they do and are very  poor technically. People making noise are dear to management. Some senior directors take care of their leads even if they are dumb a**es. I frankly don't understand the role of so called project engineers and project managers. In some money losing groups these folks outnumber engineers!
These folks are technically so poor, they don't have a future outside this company. But they are sitting here and drawing fat paychecks. Rampant favoritism in hiring and intra company transfers. I heard stories from some guys who moved from India that their buddies who had moved earlier and by now become managers, made it all too easy for them to be transferred to San Diego. Too many loud people roaming the hallways and thinking they are truly great.

review_title: Qualcomm is a great company in a perfect storm
pros: Qualcomm has amazing technology that's truly unmatched by any other would-be in the industry. It's spirit of innovation upon which it was founded still resides with many of the employees, especially at headquarters. It continues to be the leader in mobile technologies--modems and connectivity like 3G, 4G and the coming 5G. Qualcomm treats its employees very well and is generous in terms of salary and benefits.
cons: The company is in a bit of turmoil due to the on-going external attacks regarding its Licensing business, which delivers the lion's share of the company's profitability. In addition, te on-going delay in the acquisition of NXP, which was to help the company expand its footprint and TAM, has slowed the company's momentum. Note that the delay was due not to the company's short-comings, but by international politics, as China is the one remaining region to approve the acquisition. This challenge, combined with the on-going lawsuits over its licensing practices with Qualcomm's leading customer, Apple, has blended into a difficult, perfect storm for the management team.

review_title: Full-fledged member of the Cult of Shareholder Value
pros:
Up until this point the engineers were extremely talented and knowledgeable.
Working on some of the latest technologies that are widely used throughout the world is very rewarding.
cons:
Uncertainty of job security (company is going to lay-off 1/3 of it's employees.)
Even the smartest engineers have a difficult time advancing due to extremely competitive review process.
Compensation is not very compelling.

The new CEO and CFO don't seem to be acting as though they are concerned about the long term health of the company. Activist share holders, that don't seem to understand how a company like Qualcomm really makes money, have recommended Qualcomm sell off all of its profit-loosing divisions and focus on its profitable patent business. In other words: Qualcomm will soon be the patent troll to rule everything in the cellular technology field, but will have sold the profit loosing divisions that develop all of the latest cellular technologies.
