review_title: Not a great place for women
job_title: Senior Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
Big company benefits - good HR structure, opportunity to build skill and organize rest of your life around work
Smart people to work with - accomplished, modest and of great attitude.
It can be a great place to work if you are with the right manager and in the right team
Growth largely depends on the team and your role. It can be great if you are in the right place at the right time.
cons:
The percentage of women in development teams is terrible - only about 3 in every 100. This leads to several issues of gender bias, mostly unconscious.
The system is very hierarchical - management doesn't like engineers to disagree with them and any sense of disagreement can get a lot of negative attention
Performance review process is not very transparent - the manager has quiet a lot of power in it, even though the evaluation matrix includes other teams. 
Processes are not very well defined - this creates a lot of inefficiency and overhead to engineering project that the management doesn't account for in their schedules and timelines to achieve milestones

review_title: I work at their display division. Great place to work but there are some specific details that may turn you down!!
pros: Qualcomm is a great place to work. Benefits are great and you learn a lot. Every 6 months review and bonus, stock option, salary raises are good also. There are some extra-ordinary smart minds working at Qualcomm coming out with extra ordinary cutting edge technologies that is used by almost everyone who uses a mobile phone.
cons: Life can get very stressful due to company corporate politics, Bias and unfair practices. But that is there in any company you work. I found many managers/employees who are very arrogant and sneaky that makes the atmosphere very hostile sometimes. I have seen several times that my internet activities (checking personal emails, listening to music etc at work) were monitored remotely by my manager and I was informed not to do it. Most of the employees are on H1B Visa and there is a lot of manipulation by the management due to this constraint. Lot of duplication of work is common practice.

pros: Great technical expertise in the staff, driven to execute well. Large company allows everyone to be part of something that can change the world. The benefits and pay are close to the best in industry.
cons: Top management lacked foresight to position company better in a changing customer environment. While products are still profitable, margins are under pressure and cuts are the order of the day to keep the bottom line looking decent. As more cuts are made, the worse the company position becomes in applying the real changes that need to be made, causing more cuts to be necessary to stay profitable.

review_title: Really good management and great coworkers
job_title: Administrative Clerk I in Mira Mesa, CA
pros: Everyone here is super nice. At least on my team, you can go to anyone with questions and they always have answers. Unlike many places where people work without degrees (eg Vons, gas stations, retail, etc) there is opportunity to move up  (even though it may be competitive), you can get actual raises (not just like 10 cents or something silly like that), and you will be recognized for the work you put in. Although you must start as a temp, if you last a year and your managers roll you over to regular status you will instantly enjoy 11 holidays and 2 weeks of vacation. Qualcomm also has an awesome healthcare plan and generous 401K match. Oh and free food and drinks! So good....And you are only expected to work 8 hours a day (not including lunch). The job is low stress and time goes by quickly. The engineers I support are also very nice.
cons: The area is super congested and it often takes me an hour to go 15 to 20 miles. It would probably be difficult to raise a family on this income alone. I don't know how high the raises are though for sure though.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits.  Generous 401K matching; more vacation time the longer you work there; no-cost health insurance (although this is changing).  EAP.  Onsite gyms (there are several).
cons:
The company's focus has changed from the days of Dr. Jacobs.  Qualcomm had the heart of a startup, but the size and stability of a larger company.  It no longer feels stable - there have been several rounds of smaller layoffs since 2014, and a 15% reduction of force coming in September of 2015.  Admittedly, the company has gotten too big and bloated, so I do understand the layoffs; but it shouldn't have been allowed to get like that in the first place.

It no longer feels like the company is focused on innovating - just maintaining.  It's not the exciting company that it used to be.  

Folks on the IT helpdesk were not appreciated by their management (and were appreciated more by the customers), and there was favoritism - inexperienced people were promoted or retained over more experienced analysts.

review_title: Fundamentally a good company with talented, smart people
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Strong innovation culture led mostly by bright and talented individuals, Qualcomm is in a tough market with much more nimble competitors while being burdened with a bloated infrastructure and nonchalant attitude toward spending.  The Company rested on it's market dominance for too long, and their IP advantage is no longer substantial in a commodity market where product cost is paramount.  The restructuring effort underway will result in being better positioned to succeed, but the old inefficient habits die hard.  The leadership is taking bold steps to implement change but it could take longer than it should to complete and expenses are still very high.  Ultimately the company will be able to weather the shakeout of weaker competitors in the mobile phone business and expand into new markets but it really comes down to smart leadership.  This group is pretty good so the future is probably a good long-term bet.
cons: Slow consensus decision-making process hampers agility.  Some long-timers need to move on.  At times the behaviors don't match the rhetoric.  Executive micromanagement is too common.  Opportunities for career growth are rare but not impossible.

job_title: Senior IT Analyst in San Diego, CA
pros: If you get the right boss, your experience can be pleasant. Unfortunately, in my experience, there are very few good managers at QCOM. And the executives are all heartless, greedy individuals who only care about how many zeros are in their bonuses, while they put a pay freeze and eliminate bonuses for the people who actually are "lucky" enough to not be laid off...
cons: Bad management, so-so benefits that get worse each year as they keep taking more and more away from the employees, too few of people to do the work therefore there is absolutely zero work-life balance. Irwin Jacobs established a company that put people first and money second. Since the Jacobs are no longer running the company, the company treats there people HORRIBLY! In my group, we have 1/3 of the employees as we did 5 years ago and twice as much work. You do the math --- Massive amount of work + a third of a workforce = 80-90 hour work weeks... with no overtime, no bonus, no raise. I wonder why the attrition rate is through the roof, and no one wants to come to the company, so positions stay open for 15 months?????

review_title: Great company to invest in, but not to work at.
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Still the leader in wireless.  Lightyears ahead of other mobile chip makers.
cons:
Qualcomm has had lots of burn out in the past couple years.  During my exit interview, the HR person mentioned they are seeing a gradual increase in employees leaving due to burn out.  I'm still in contact with my old co-workers there and it's the same story: long hours, constant pressure to meet aggressive schedules.  

If you are hell bent on working at Qualcomm, avoid the QCT division.  They work their engineers like dogs there.  I was part of the modem group when I left and they had the most aggressive working hours.

While I still worked there, a QCT engineer committed suicide in 2010 which made big news, but there was another recent QCT suicide in June of 2012 that was hush hush possibly due to timing of a big PR announcement.  This is what my sources who still work here tell me.  Very sad.

review_title: Above Average Employer operating in an unstable industry
pros:
1. Good compensation
2. Historically amazing career growth (not sure if true currently)
3. Decent non-cash benefits
4. Overall great people
5. Good reputation, adds to personal credibility
cons:
1. In the chips (VLSI) division, there's too much drudgery and not enough challenges. Too high an emphasis on timelines and deliverables, creating work pressure without the benefit of the job satisfaction counter-balance
2. Company and overall industry not doing well
3. Too heavily reliant on a few major players, career at risk
4. Several management issues, at least in Bangalore (India), too many failed restructuring attempts, I've also heard multiple persistent grumbles about strong politics-driven culture for advancements in higher strata (not verified by me, but likely true)
5. Poor work-life balance

pros: Qualcomm used to be one of the most exciting company to work for.  The company was very generous to provide various benefits directly and indirectly.   We were working hard, countless long days, but we were very happy and we were taken care of when the reviews came.
cons: Looks like Qualcomm hasn't come up with the 2nd biggest idea to bring success to the company.  CDMA was the cash cow and it has been the only cash cow.  As technology moving forward to 4G, 5G, the company is only be more difficult to be the king of its domain.  Worse that the company has been growing. Now it is a huge company, so more people are sharing the smaller and smaller cake.

job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Free sodas in the break room, an office with a door, lots of vacation time.
cons: Three pay cuts this year. The first in the form of a benefits cut that took our health benefit from one of the best in the country to one of the worst. The second in the form of the announcement that there are no more bonuses. The third in the form of the rest of the investing world recognizing that our business decisions are really bad and dumping our stock like a load of moldy garbage, causing us to fall nearly 50% since the moment the Jana Group bought us out and replaced our board's visionaries with spineless used car salesmen.

pros:
1. Good package specially for lead and above level. 
2. Yearly twice review cycles. 
3. Colleagues are helpful. 
4. Not many Intelligent people so no competition even average guy can be top performer.
5. Good stock plans.
cons:
1.  Qualcomm is not for intelligent people. Growth is purely based on experience not on performance. If you are a good performer might get 20% more stock or bonus but no career growth. 
2. No dedicated training sessions. Qualcomm conducts good Webinar and trainings but you have to make time to attend the training. Because of workload even though you are interested may not be able to attend the sessions. 
3. Too many unnecessary meetings. Most of the meetings are at US time . no conclusion on meetings. 
4. Too many bad decisions from upper management resulted in recent layoff. 
5. Quality of work is very bad in qualcomm hyderabad middle management is very pushy in nature. Don't know to handle things only thing they know is to put pressure on lower layer.
6. Partiality towards temp employees for any company events they are not invited. 
7. Very less travelling opportunities.

review_title: Good job if you find a position you like
job_title: Staff Engineer  in San Diego, CA
pros: Good place that supports employees and has a bright future.  The salary and benefits are good and the management is responsive and looks out for the employees.  The company itself is in an excellent position, with lots of cash and a position to keep its prominence in the field into the future.  So if you can get into a high design position, you'll get to work on a lot of cool and upcoming technologies.  The daily routine, the physical plant, the offices, the work environment are very pleasant.  Overall, a job here is a nice, safe, good job to have.
cons: The hassles of a huge corporation, being put into a tiny role.  This may be my personal prejudice coming out here, but I've asked to do more and try more variety in what I work on, but I can't get out of my own tiny job now.  The manager thinks there's too much for me to do, so I'm spending all my time on a job I'm bored with.  So I may personally have to leave soon, but that's just my specific story.

pros: good benefit good location good name
cons: very racist. Very political bad management

pros: Good in terms of salary and facilities
cons: I work for the chip designing domain in  this company. Iam not sure about the software wing but then iam not very satisified with physical and chip design field. The deadlines are extremely stringent and there is no work life balance. People have to work like maniancs for 3 to 5 days without sleep. If you join this company especially in this wing please forget your personal life and that u have a family. The upper management is crazy people. No recognition for hardwork and technical expertise. There are some non techies who do not have even enough knowledge to judge who is hardworking and who has extraordinary competency. People with real knowhow and expertise are discouraged and not given any hikes or promotions. There's all dirty politics happening. The upper management is not very good at planning the work and as a result the techies who work are under acute mental pressure and stress every time. Inhuman work culture

job_title: Program Manager in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Some great minds still work there
- Reasonably good benefits (used to be much better, however)
- Used to be an absolutely awesome company. Is it possible for that to happen again?
cons:
- A top-heavy company, resulting in a horribly political environment with much backstabbing as all levels of management try to "make their mark" without regard for the inefficiencies resulting from most of their initiatives.
- A tough company for females!
- A Culture of Fear: an environment where high level executives decide it is OK to yell at everyone in every single meeting instead of leading by example and identifying the real problems that are occurring within Qualcomm. Note to Bosses: If you are yelling at everyone, feeling that your whole team is lacking, maybe you are the problem, not your team. Turn inward, work with your team in a positive manner, and fix the issues!

job_title: Senior Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: I worked on a small team that thrived under good management - we were encouraged to find new solutions, given reasonable goals, and for the most part I felt valued as a team member. Great pay, great health benefits (until 2016), and flexible work schedule due to long hours (meaning I could work from home after hours). Sadly, my team and I were affected by the 2015 layoff.
cons: Favoritism is rampant in upper management, they will move their friends into departments for "process improvement" with little or no experience. It's typically disastrous to the team as they try to please the new management while making improvements that are not helpful. It's a lose-lose deal. Everyone is also over-worked and therefore unwilling to adopt any new process that costs their team any time or effort, even it the long term gain outweighs the short-term learning curve. Promotions are difficult if you are not playing the political game.

review_title: Worst company if you want to learn and keep growing your skills
pros:
Actually present environment has changed much. Now Qualcomm is also like other medium paying companies. 
Pros - 
1. you can file your ideas in portal and if it's unique company will apply for a patent grant and you will get some benefit as well.
2. 110 rs. daily free food
3. Adequate medical insurance
4. Team outings
cons:
1. Bureaucracy and politics
2. Management is so crude and no matter how talented you are and how much you work. They will promote you only after completing 3 years and more.
3.   Yearly review cycle and that's also not sure how much hike you will get as it depends on overall earnings which are shrinking year by year in competitive mobile chipset market.
4. Huge work load. you take one week leave and management thinks you were not working from last 6 months.
5. Learning areas are very shrink and regular work load is more. which will make you tire and unfit to outside world job market.
6. Most of the teams has no coding work, So you will forget all the programming knowledge and while looking for new job, you will have to study all your programming basics again.
7. Telugu speaking people are benefited specially in Hyderabad location

review_title: Career Growth and middle management review
job_title: Staff Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: The upper management is extremely good at seeing problems and fixing them before they become a major issue. They are very smart in how they handle the finances and the market. Overall a happy stable enviroment in an industry where there is so much turmoil
cons: The middle management is extremely weak. So many old timers who were good or excellent engineers have been promoted to middle managers and they are doing a very poor job of managing the day to day activity and the engineers under them. This makes for a highly stressful and inefficient work environment on a day to day basis resulting in long hours for most engineers.

review_title: Was a great company - now not sure!
pros: Benefits, compensation, bonus and stock plans, smart people all around you, world leaders in what they do, working on cutting edge technologies etc
cons: Giant that still runs like a start up in many ways, reviews are relative rather than absolute (that is you always get compared to the next person no matter how good you might have done independently)

review_title: Good only for people with Electronics Background, not for CS
pros:
1) Good Salary, even as a fresher, best in telecommunication domain
2) Good exposure to a lot of cut-edge technologies, esp in mobile domain
3) If you are lucky, few people are very helping and polite in solving all your doubts
cons:
1) Culture has went bad over recent years and a lot of work overload is being faced by employees, work life balance completely lost. Also politics among teams has led to an adverse work distribution among employees.
2) Only testing and debugging work given to freshers, hardly any development work done, bad esp for people with CS background
3) Salary hikes are pretty bad compared to other companies in the same salary domain.
4) Collaborating with US guys is a big issue, you have to work and collaborate till late hours everyday, which leads to a very bad work-life balance and you just cant feel free even after coming home

review_title: Good benefits, okay compensation...be prepared to work
job_title: Senior Manager in San Diego, CA
pros:
nice company with great benefits. lots of opportunity to move to different areas and I have seen people grow by having jobs created for them. great activities for employees (such as picnics, evenings out, summer employee music/outdoor events) and a lot of learning resources available to take advantage of. 

We get free medical and dental benefits which is a definite plus and something I have not seen at other companies.
cons:
There are a few draw backs to working at QCT:
QCT has a totally different culture than the rest of Qualcomm
QCT employees work an excessive amount of time, often with little recognition
Within QCT there is a lot of critical speak that goes on, have thick skin if you join 
The QCT culture is one of putting out fires -- don't expect a lot of planning to happen to prevent these fires
If you are on the business side you need to realize that there is not a lot of recognition outside of engineers

review_title: QCT continues to be a sweatshop
pros:
It's exciting to work on latest and greatest technologies.  QCT is all about executing and there are many hardworking folks who take pride in commercializing many of today's mobile technologies.

The insurance benefits are great.  Nice 401k match as well.  I am glad they recently diced stock options in favor of RSU for most employees.
cons: QCT continues to bring in most of the revenue and profits and QCT engineers end up spending 12+ hours a day working in the labs and responding to round the clock emails from San Diego, Boulder, Raleigh and India offices.  Other divisions don't work as hard and the company does not recognize QCT engineer premium in salaries and bonuses.  It's hard to justify to my family why I work in QCT v/s transfer to another department with same salary, benefits and in the same company.

review_title: Product driven company with significant blind spots
pros: Excellent pay, very smart people, good benefits.
cons: Extremely limited opportunities for promotion and advancement in marketing.

review_title: Good starting point for career in Silicon Valley
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Qualcomm has some cool hardware teams in Silicon Valley. 
- Can be a great place to pick up some embedded software or test engineering skills.
- Good work-life balance
- Free drinks/sodas
cons:
- Not as many opportunities as San Diego HQ
- Feels like projects in the Bay Area are treated as experimental, and HQ is fine cutting entire teams/divisions
- Takes a little too long to get promoted. Some employees deserve a promotion at least a year before it finally happens.
- Salary is noticeably less than similar companies nearby, but Qualcomm's health, bonuses, and RSU program outweigh most companies.

pros: Good salary and one of the best companies in San Diego (not a lot of other options if you live in SD).
cons: Not the awesome company it used to be. It used to be an innovative company with top talent, however, with morale declining, continuous layout offs/restructuring, little or no career path and growth and mid level management, people are looking elsewhere. It's become an old, stale company.   Merit has decrease - bonuses are basically non-existent even for top performers.  Healthcare is expensive - huge difference when we went from amazing healthcare to horrible overnight. Too many drastic changes hit all at once rather than easing through the these transitions.

review_title: Full of smart people who are highly knowledgeable in wireless communications
pros:
There's a reason why Qualcomm is often listed in Best Places to Work surveys.  Management makes sure to listen to employee concerns, needs, and wants, in order to improve working conditions as well as work-life balance.  At times, they are even proactive about introducing new ideas to make working at Qualcomm better.

Not only that, working at Qualcomm gave me the opportunity to work with and learn from very smart and experienced people in the field of wireless communications.  Since many of these people are the pioneers in the field, I was able to get a sneak peek at upcoming technologies--and everybody was open and willing to share with me.  People (even some quite senior members) are generally happy to chat, no matter how busy they are.
cons: Since it's a large company, sometimes it seems that an individual's contribution does not impact the company much.  The managers do try, however, to recognize the contributions, even if it doesn't eventually pan out.

job_title: Senior Staff Engineer  in San Jose, CA
pros: Irwin's legacy is a strong engineering culture.  This for the most part thrives.  I like the underdog mentality that was  developed through the history of CDMA
cons:
Can get a bit insular and cocky at times within the company.  We invented CDMA, but in other areas the company still needs to still needs to work on improving efficiency.

Sometimes people assume that every new business is going to be as successful as the CDMA licensing business, but I think people have to remember that things didn't just happen easily for Irwin and team.  They had to really struggle to prove the efficiency of the technology, and even then there were some tough times for the company.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Qualcomm - QCT - is full of surprises. It is a great place to work, and there are many things that are good for the employee: great employee relations, HR helps ensure manager apply consistent rules, and the benefits are good. You get a review every 6 months and get formal feedback each time.
cons: Here are the surprises: the management mindset is very much to reward the fire fighters, not the good managers who prevent the fires in the first place. There is great focus on execution and the delivery of quality product. However there is less attention to addressing inefficiencies. QCT runs many projects in parallel and does a good job as this. If I compare lower profile less interesting but high volume projects with the high profile, more interesting lower volume projects - the latter always get into trouble (because they are complex) and so get all the attention, and these team members seem to be better rewarded than the low profile teams who do a good job (and so don't need management attention).

review_title: Smart young people leaving the company
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Good to get ~3 yrs experience before jumping ship to google or any other place
cons: I see lots of frustration from the sr engineer level to sr dir level. It seems no one is capable of making any decision and everyone is chasing others for approval. There is a lot of confusion around decision making and it feels like the dmv. None of the current leaders have any vision. Infact none of the current leaders have an accomplishment to show around creating a successful new business. They know how to scale one but that is not useful when the core business is under threat. The CEO has probably spoken in coded words to employees after every analyst call. It was hardly inspirational. The corporate research group is a joke and has lost its way. I know a lot of people in the research group either biding their time or wanting to leave.

review_title: Great place in a great city
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer/Manager in San Diego, CA
pros:
Qualcomm is still able to attract some of the smartest people. I think the smartness density has gone down somewhat over the years but people are still above the industry average. 
Qualcomm offers excellent benefits in health plan, vacation, flex time. Facilities are excellent with multiple gyms available (at least in San Diego location). Norm is to provide an individual office for all engineers which I think is an excellent idea for engineering.
cons:
Qualcomm pay is competitive but is not top rung. Given Qualcomm's size stock options don't have as much upside. 
I have my doubts about our current CEO, Paul Jacobs. 
Qualcomm has been very strong in systems and communication theory, but weak in software. There are lot of smart s/w engineers and s/w makes up a large chunk of engineering, but the number of VPs is still more skewed towards comm theory.

review_title: Great place to work for entry level engineers but lot a glut in middle management
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer/Manager in San Diego, CA
pros:
Some divisions are better than others. QCT is a good place to work because it generate consistent cash for the company. QIS, MediaFlo and other divisions are not as good because the respective businesses are not doing well. 

Excellent healthcare plan.

Good vacation package.

For most part you can expect a stable work environment and surrounded by generally high quality people..

Consistent pay raises
cons:
bonuses are erratic. Stock options are not worth much nowadays. So unless the company gives RSU's the compensation package is not very attractive. 

attrition rate is very low so there is a glut of managers who dont have enough work to do. this is leading to a politically charged environment

review_title: Great company for engineers, bad place for marketing or brand professionals
pros: Great employee benefits, good technology.
cons:
The company is a technology company that listens to its engineers but does not understand to listen to marketing or brand professionals it hires. When plans don't work they lay off entire divisions and the marketing folks are AWOL. I have many friends who lost jobs due to the company's treatment of marketing professionals, who they place no value on.  Qualcomm does not understand or value marketing, brand, sales - it's a technology company.
Many divisions are started by FOP (Friends of Paul (Jacobs) inexperienced senior management, who have no experience in marketing or branding, and come up with their own marketing ideas, fail to properly fund, follow through  or persist with the marketing or brand campaigns, don't listen to the marketing experts, and then fold the division when the sales don't work out.  Then they fire the marketing staff, start all over again with a new product and do the same mistakes:  complete lack of consumer insight.
They know technology, not consumers.

review_title: Politics everywhere - especially tech comms team
pros: good pay, but that isnt everything
cons:
Biased managers
Prejudiced decisions during hiring process
Only one person can grow from a junior writer to a director in 10 years :) - ridiculous growth! 
Unwanted processes
Hire only from the growth perspective of the existing people - no major work per se
Open door policy is only going to back fire - no point in complaining
Siblings and cousins work it out very well - especially people from North India
Though a company set up in Hyderabad, it is a place for north indians - I am not against them, but give preference to the others as well.

review_title: Very comfortable job but no motivation to work very hard
job_title: Investment Manager in San Diego, CA
pros:
Easy and flexible work hours. No pressure.
Great travel and benefits. Very loose reimbursement policy.
Loved independence as worked from home most days. Most of office able to work from home. 
Paid more than QCT peers and buddies but work much less. 20% more. Too good to be true at times.
Loved San Diego.  perfect environment if you have family.
cons:
Lots of bureaucracy. So slow for us to move  to get deals done.   
Everyone who was good at QCV moved on to better jobs and funds.  No one really left who I  respect.
New leadership really lazy and can't make decisions. Very very slow.
Review process was demoralizing.  Hated it.
Loads of politics and backstabbing. Just ignore and you will be fine.  But dont expect help.

review_title: Highly bureaucratic company, be vary of HR 's when you join Qualcomm.
pros: -> You can do a lot of work without getting paid much.
cons:
- > Qualcomm HR is really really bad and they try to take advantage of people thats why they always go and hire people from companies who have recently laid off people because in desperate times people are ready to  take up any position and at any salary, they specially do that with international's working here. I have not seen any other similar company do this.

-> Qualcomm wants you to work all day and night and then doesn't want to reward you for it, not even a pat on the back.

-> they have tons of directors, yes Qualcomm likes to give lofty positions to people and they have so much hierarchy in terms of positions that a person joining at a lower level feels like a useless worm here.

-> the so called upper management never cares to talk to employees.

-> Promotion system is totally vague and seems highly unjust.

review_title: Very good mix of roses and thorns.
pros: Great benefits, and resources, senior people are fairly well compensated. Lot of interesting work, great colleagues, good diversity, strong industry presence, sustained competitive advantage.
cons: Company is becoming too large, and top heavy. I feel there is a fair amount of dead wood, some house cleaning would be useful.  Engineers have relatively little room for lateral movements.   Lots of duplication.  Would like product management, marketing to be more competent. Stock price has been up and down over the last 10 years, but relatively flat (or even down), some competitors did better.   The management can be very agressive in goals, w/o backing up with resources. This creates a lot stress on the team.  However, this varies from division to division. QCT (CDMA Technologies) is the busiest place to work at, but also the safest in terms of job security.

review_title: Has been good, unsure about the future
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: No monthly premium on healthcare, RSU and bonus' twice yearly, provide plenty of resources for self-training (pluralsight, lynda.com, safari books).
cons: Completely unstable in the current environment. Good employees are wary and looking for other opportunities. Senior executive managers have made ludicrous statements about how their business plan was perfect but the market just didn't show up. Lots of organizational change occurring for the foreseeable future. Recently changed healthcare plan to require deductible (equals an effective pay cut). Additionally, QC has a very passive-aggressive culture even in the best of time.

pros:
Some awesome engineers around. If they don't see you as a threat, you will get to learn a thing or two.
Decent perks.
cons:
Rampant nepotism.

Managers hiring 'loyal' people from their previous orgs, their boss's/peer's wives, and they all live in a happily ever after, where they scratch each other's backs.

If the San Diego overlords are happy(or you can make it look like you are doing good), you can get away with anything. Even if the entire team report who reports to you, complaints to upper management, they will not do anything because, end of day its all about business.

There is no thing as ethics, decent behavior or even decent language. You will be punished for not being complacent, threatened for asking questions.

Have personally witnessed  employees tortures and pushed into depression because they could not get along with the middle management.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros:
* Get to work with some talented people (occasionally)
* The technology being developed is the future of communications and computing
* Company makes a lot of money
* Executive management has a clear vision of where they want to go
cons:
* Largely incompetent management at the SVP level and below (engineers who can't manage)
* Most SVPs and below wouldn't know a good decision if it hit them in the face
* Focused on "returning value to stockholders" at the expense of making good decisions
* Appear to be moving most work off-shore, which is cheaper but quality suffers
* VERY political: lots of back-stabbing
* Executive management lets outside consultants (BCG, Accenture, others) put into place cookie-cutter management strategies with little oversight (too busy working on "the big picture" to care)

review_title: Work is good but a very Toxic culture
job_title: Senior Software Systems Test Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Work is good, Lot to learn, people are dedicated and hardworking
- you get a lot of material to help you 
- Tuition reimburse
- Lot of training to choose from
- ESPP program and bonus at year end
cons:
- Politics Politics Politics !!
- Toxic work culture [not generic][specific to the org I was working ]
- Totally Biased towards certain groups/factions 
- Most of the times, work is randomly assigned and deadlines are given to unnecessarily pressurize you, while it is clearly not relevant .. There will be pressure almost every week, but at the end of the year .. you will ask yourself why the hell, what did I achieve ?  
- No transparency , Low morale 
- work life balance is not encouraged 
- No-one cares, you feel merely a number 
- Low Base pay, but probably something is being addressed ,

review_title: Slow degradation of a great company
job_title: IT Engineer, Staff in San Diego, CA
pros: Work with highly talented people. Your skill set will improve and strengthen.  Produce a product that will touch billions of people throughout the world. A great company to have on your resume.
cons: Internal job opportunities are available, but rarely completed. From the time I started until the day I left, the company was completely different. The vision and direction was no longer there. Qualcomm is considered to be one of the most innovating and forward thinking companies in the world. Unfortunately, that opinion is slowly eroding.

review_title: Great company but leadership plays favorites
pros: I worked at Qualcomm for 6 years and consider it to be some of the best years of my 10+ year career. I learned a lot about the telecommunications industry and became a better professional while working there. I also got to interact with a lot of senior leadership and worked on some really interesting projects, including a video project that featured Qualcomm's leaders and its augmented reality technology.
cons:
Within the department where I worked, leadership played favorites. I found that I was passed up for a promotion a few time because the "decision makers" wanted someone else to be promoted over me. Decisions to promote were not based on merit alone and politics played a huge role. 
I also found that performance plans were not adhered to that regularly. We had them and discussed them with our managers every 6 months but goals weren't measured in a manner that yielded a consistent result.

review_title: Qualcomm - Not The Company It Use To Be
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros:
+ Industry leader
+ Opportunity to work with leading-edge technology
+ Challenging work environment
+ Diverse workforce
+ Fairly compensated for the amount of work that is expected of you
cons:
- Low employee morale due to recent layoffs and cost-cutting moves.
- Company laid off ~15% of employees in 2015.  Focus seemed to be on getting rid of the "expensive" employees who had been loyal, committed employees for 8 years or longer.
- Cost cutting moves have taken away many of the things that made Qualcomm a great place to work.  Gone are the superb health benefits, lunches & Friday morning bagels, beverages in all conference rooms, celebrations/parties for tapeouts, annual holiday parties, etc.
- No work/life balance.  Expectation in many groups that work will continue from home in the evenings and on weekends.
- Questionable hiring/promotion practices that are based upon a person's ethnicity and whether it aligns with senior leadership.

review_title: Young Engineers Go Elsewhere (run don't walk);  Older Q worker's try to retool and find another place that is growing.
pros:
-nice San Diego laid back culture; not as cuthroat as some of the new tech places.
-hard wall offices w/ a door for a lot of people
- decent peers
- a techie's dream but not so great on the business side
- compensation pack was good though 2015.
cons:
-"has been" tech company (best years were mid 1990s to 2015), i.e. young engineers go elsewhere
- very top heavy in titles
- rolling layoffs w/ staggered exit dates so as not to trigger WARN act.
- CFO running the ship in 2017.
- no vision; still stuck in the past of 1) new products need patent licensing model and 2) how to move a bit from here to there quicker.
- merging w/ NXP soon which has been a bigger headcount, i.e. more layoffs.
 - everything in R&D a couple of degree separation from mainline of business.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Company is a market leader and strongly positioned in it's core cellular modem business. It is growing steadily. This translates to job security.
Very good benefits package, one could say it's on par with the best out there.  
Smart people to work with (definitely in the group I work in). Good learning process for fresh grads.
cons:
Compensation is average, esp if you are in bay area. Bonuses, RSUs and benefits may make up for it partly but still not on par with most SF Bay Area biggies.
Work life balance is bad and getting worse progressively as the years pass on. I feel that I am spending more weekends working now compared to earlier. Processes (documentation, communication) havent kept pace with the transition to a big multi-time zone company. 
There are a lot of personal development opportunities, but rarely does one have the chance to put off work and take even a 3-day class.
Career growth within the company is slowing down. This is mainly due to crowding at higher levels of the company that is throttling the growth of lower and mid-levels.

review_title: Grass is definitely not greener there
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Qualcomm has a reputation of being a good employer but the only thing I enjoyed was meeting new friends.
cons:
This place is not what it's cracked up to be. Probably the worst experience I've had to endure for the last few years. Bad management (boys club exclusive), no vision for our team, middle mgmt don't care either ( only there for their own agenda). Q needs to clean house and get rid of those middle managers who just do not work or do nothing to motivate their people. Fact: there is no opportunity to review upward... so assumption is that all mgrs are doing well. hope the next couple of workforce reduction rounds gets them out - it's a toxic environment. 

Steer clear - benefits will no longer be premier (high deductible and moving to banking your $$ for medical expenses), annual reviews starting next year (no longer twice yearly bonus, RSUs, raises), unlimited vacation (so they no longer have to pay you if they lay you off), limited sick (no longer allowed to take as many days), etc. 

Stay away.

review_title: Big company with limited career opportunities unless you work a lot of overtime
pros:
- successful company with good financial status
- pockets of good people and good teams
- small areas with challenging design work
- flexible in work hours and schedule
cons:
- a fair number of engineers have limited social and teamwork skills (to be expected based on the interview process)
- work is not very challenging, mostly mindless bug fixes and porting
- has fully transitioned to a big company that rewards heavy overtime but not anything else (wasn't this way originally)
- promotes weak leaders who attempt to use fear (shouting, etc.) to motivate
- highly directed work, low creativity, very strict adherence to processes (many of them weak or even detrimental to the business)
- feedback for improvement no longer considered by upper management

review_title: Was once a great place to be at
pros: At one time the work-life balance was great and had a really good group of employees and management however that changed for the worse in the past five years.
cons:
Benefits and salary were great however they were almost too good if you try to find a job other than at Qualcomm.  You will find you are over titled and over paid; I say this both as a former QC employee who was trying to find other work as well as someone who is now a manager at another company trying to hire and getting plenty of applicants from QC.

Huge shift in employee demographics changed the landscape of the company and became very back-stabbing and was emotionally draining.  Was glad to get out of the company and see how much better things are outside of "The Q".

review_title: Great experience and smart people.  Constantly working with new projects and new challenges as business grows.
job_title: Accounting Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Great working experiences, smart people, great pay and benefits. Wonderful cross-functional support and teamwork. Exiting company to work for.
cons: Giant company = giant bureaucracy and limited scope.  As far as your workplace experience, your mileage will vary, depending on what group you work in and who you work for.  There are some wonderful leaders in upper mgt, and also some who really don't deserve to be there.  Most higher ranking positions are increasingly filled externally, rather than promoting from within.

review_title: Alas, not the great company that it used to be
job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in San Diego, CA
pros: There are many opportunities to learn new tools, skills, and technologies here, and a lot of great employee perks like free online educational programs, if you take advantage of them. The pay and benefits are still among the best in San Diego.
cons: The atmosphere no longer feels like a family like it did when the Jacobs family was calling the shots. The primary focus seems to be on the stock price, rather than on innovation. They got the U.S. president to save the company from the Broadcom hostile takeover, but the company is still outsourcing jobs by the hundreds.

pros: Good health benefits and stock purchase discount. Good gym, lot of celebrations, lots of lunch meetings (free food). There are plenty of technical courses that will enable you to keep up to date professionally. There are a lot of non work related mailing lists that you can join for areas of your interest. If you get the right assignment work can be interesting and cutting edge when it comes to the industry peers.
cons: Qualcomm organisation lacks structure. If you have worked at a process driven company it takes time to understand how things function. Qualcomm is also an old boys club. If you know someone higher up or have been there for years and are well connected you will not have a problem, otherwise you are going to remain where you are. if you stay at QCOM for several years then eventually some of the stock options will be worth money.

review_title: Qualcomm, the amazing company everyone should want to work at!
pros: I have great people to work with in an amazingly non-corporate corporate atmosphere. Employment includes a tremendous benefits package that's unrivaled by any in the industry. In my job I'm always working with cutting-edge technology that you can't find anywhere else in the world. In short, I love my job.
cons: Sometimes you'll work long hours, but when you enjoy what you're doing, that's hardly a downside. If for some reason you don't like San Diego, that could be an issue, but there are also smaller offices in Boulder CO, India, Campbell CA, and RTP NC. Qualcomm has been known to play hardball (lots of litigation, good patent portfolio, etc), so if you're a fan of "everyone must play equal" stuff, this might not be the place for you.

review_title: Excellent Place to work, Great Benefits
pros:
Qualcomm is one the best companies to work for. The salary is above national average and Qualcomm is one of the high paying companies. The benefits are really awesome, you get full health care coverage with very little copay. 

If you are ambitious and hard working, Qualcomm is really good company to start your career and move forward.
cons:
Sometimes the work gets hectic. Salary although high and Qualcomm is among best paying companies, it still not as high as compared to other giants like Google or Microsoft. Hence Qualcomm may have issues in retaining talent.

Bonuses and stocks are given to employees but again they could be much higher.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Qualcomm employs and encourages some of the brightest minds and hard working and hard playing employees in the country, possibly in the world. Benefits were the best you could get (though that's changing) and there are numerous perks. The culture values employee development, innovation, and engagement and the experience and on the job training gained is first rate, possibly unparalleled.
cons: Management and culture is overrun, almost crippled, by nuanced political rules and games.  Bureaucracy and legal and security fearmongering slow product and business development, by months, if not years. Critical opportunities have been missed and millions wasted. There is a brand awareness and competitive value proposition problem that must be put to bed and continuously cultivated.

review_title: Earn at cost of your personal life. Worst Experience
pros:
1)Brand name
2)Good Compensation & stock options
3)Sometimes tasks are interesting
cons:
1)No space for personal life. You might need to work 12-15 hours a day on average. If you forget your personal life, you can survive. I didn't use the word work-life balance because there is no life at all.
2)Expectations are more, since your peers are living to work, you also have to live to work.
3)No training for tasks. You have to dive and swim. Cannot expect proper guidance to everyone.
4)Change in location/teams is very tedious. The teams are not assigned based on skillset.
5)Policies are favoring the company not the employees. HRs use the word, "as per the policy", whenever you are raising any concerns. Your concerns are often turned down. 
6)You have adjust to team timing. Even when you are leaving at 5pm in the evening, you might need to mail "Leaving Early Today"

job_title: Senior Staff Engineer/Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: You live in San Diego.
cons:
Too stressful! HR has been trying to improve work life balance but the culture is suffering from the vicious circle. If you don't work late night and weekends your review and bonus suffers. Despite the lip service "we must reward productivity and not long hours". 

Too many a holes are being promoted despite the CEO's claim "we don't promote a-holes". HR does not protect the individuals from retaliation from higher ups unless where the retaliation might create legal problems (e.g. sexual harassment)

review_title: Once up on a good company, lost its edge in current competition
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
* some of the very finest engineers to work with in Wireless industry
* very open and collaborative  environment where you can learn and grow in career.
* Good health-care coverage even-though recently high deductible has been added (very much comparable with Apple, Google, FB)
cons:
* Negative atmosphere due to multiple lawsuits made this company to go from "best company to work for" to "not so good company to work for" (Basically, from year 2015 to 2018 and counting are the worst of worst years in Qualcomm history).

* No matter how good the current CEO is trying, his luck is not favoring. CEO is kind of caught up in fights from multiple ends, so company is loosing the focus and valuable/experience talent.

* Salary is below than competitor company.  Pay-scale is as per year 2014 in 2018.

review_title: Great benefits in return for 50+ hr work weeks.
job_title: Senior Program Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: The benefits are amazing.  Great healthcare paid in full by Qualcomm.  They have a free health clinic and great cafeterias.
cons:
They are not doing well as competitors are taking the lead in the industry.  They are experiencing major layoffs, which include employees who have been with the company 15+ years.  
Management is also a bit of a joke.  Too many top-level leaders without enough worker bees.  This results in major ego battles.  At times the antics felt more like a high school feud than productive management expected from a leading technology company.

job_title: Senior Staff Engineer/Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Great if you are from Asia and have total disregard for American employment laws called EOE that Americans hold dearly
cons:
Good luck if you are an American. This company loves H1B's and asians
Merit increases statistically are ethnicity/gender and ethnicity/gender of your boss.   
E.g.
Female with Female boss:        25% merit increase & director promotion path especially if incompetent
Chinese with Chinese boss:      20% merit increase & promotion
Indian with Chinese boss:         2% merit & no promotion
Indian with Indian boss:           25% merit increase & promotion
Chinese with American boss:   Same as everyone else - there's a EOE law that American's are obliged by
Indian with American boss:     Same as everyone else - there's a EOE law that American's are obliged by
Other:                                          Good luck- take the package

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Large, Established company that will probably take many years to go all the way down the toilet
cons:
Incompetent Management
Obsolete Business Model
Layoffs, Demotions and Pay Cuts
Low Employee Morale
Decreasing Stock Value
Highly Political Work Environment
Commodity Product
Unfair Employment Practice

review_title: Still the king of Mobile semiconductor business
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: I joined Qualcomm in 2005 after graduating with Masters degree. It was the best company I could ask for employment. The engineers in our group and the groups we interacted with are super smart. I learned a lot during the first few years. Some Pros are 1) Big company where you can get lot of opportunities to move around 2) New grads can learn a lot from smart employee base. 3) Lot of talks/seminars for employees to grow their knowledge.
cons: Management should have been a little more proactive in looking for new opportunities outside mobile space. They are starting to do it now with drones and IoT. But they were in an enviable position a few years ago where they could have had a significant first mover advantage. But knowing the talent pool there, I believe they will be able to find new opportunities in the next 2 to 3 years.

pros: Still better than many companies that one could work for - in a good industry, lots of smart people, fewer opportunities than before but still affords opportunities for people
cons: Although Qualcomm is still probably better than many companies, it is far from what it used to be.  The company seems to have lost its way in how it treats and supports its employee base.  It used to provide a competitive pay and benefits package and had many leaders who were not only smart, but also just good people who put the needs of the team and company over their own self-interests.  The pay and benefits packages are no longer competitive and the culture of the organization has definitely changed and not for the better as new leaders have been brought in or promoted. This isn't a reflection of the HR organization but rather a reflection of the entire executive management team.

pros:
1. Benefits like free meals 3 times (giving 2 rating just because of it :P).
2. Company stocks program.
3. Most of the time work life balance is there.
cons:
1. Too much politics (south vs north) and (senior vs junior).
2. Working with old people is quite difficult, They don't encourage to think new or do something out of box.
3. Pay is well below market standard.
4. Managers are worst here, don't care about work ethics (can shout at anyone in work hours).
5. The process of norms is too much lengthy. So, work efficiency gets affected.
6. No clear division of work among engineers.
7. Scope of learning is very less and learning rate will become 0 after 1 year(same repetitive work again and again).
8. I worked in a team which was full of seniors people only and when i joined i was fresher so, they don't used to consider us as a significant resource.

review_title: Why Wait? (to leave this sinking ship)
job_title: Business Development in San Diego, CA
pros: Pretty good products, still has strong market position in mobile, people are eager to succeed, a fast-paced organization
cons:
A COMPANY IN PRECIPITOUS DECLINE.

Endless politics in building "N" and stretching well beyond, 90% of managers' time is spend on things that are by definition useless (show & tell), backstabbing, endless bureaucracy, you can accomplish nothing without legal and legal by definition don't give a damn, QCT (chip business) is quickly losing market share, unrealistic expectations from engineers (luckily I'm not there), egregious benefits for our pompous execs, very hierarchical and title oriented, more than 70 Senior VPs many without the foggiest about people management skills, unethical licensing business model, very short term focus (all profits go out to dividends and buybacks), why wait?

pros: Flex-time off policy and some smart engineers
cons:
Talent isn’t appreciated in this company at all. It’s a very political place, with a lot of political power given to directors of groups. So if your director is good, you can get better salary, better bonuses and timely promotions.
If your director isn’t good, good luck getting promoted even to senior engineer (btw promotion = 10k salary increase, which is way too small).

If you are in remote site (not in SD that is), good luck with finding opportunities for career growth within the company. Utterly disgraceful management, with loads of VPs reporting each other, who do nothing valuable for growth of this company. Upper management doesn’t really care for even basic needs of engineers (like monumental pay increase, creating work-friendly environment). Review system is biased and managers don’t really care about third party opinions (why even take them, if you don’t care about them?)

There are better companies out there. Avoid like plague.

review_title: QCT is a tough place to work... know what you are getting yourself into
job_title: Senior Design Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Being on the cutting edge of the wireless industry.  You gain visibility into technologies and business decisions that will influence the rest of the world.  Best employer in San Diego, which is a fantastic city to live in.  There are really no other good chip design companies within SD... in fact it's hard to find other good technology companies in San Diego.  Nothing compared to Irvine or Bay Area
cons: QCT is not a great place to work.  Most within QCT view themselves as "Quality Control Technicians".  The culture needs to change and the engineers need to be better appreciated.
